line_1: When thus to Heaven he makes his last appeal.
line_2: Fearless who dares his inmost thoughts reveal,

line_1: To the kind heart alone thou dost appeal,
line_2: And bidst th' ingenuous there conviction feel.

line_1: To yon sour dog I first appeal.
line_2: Let each his discontent reveal.

line_1: To Syllable-dissectors they appeal,
line_2: Allow them accent, cadence, — Fools may feel;

line_1: Why would you hear his strange appeal,
line_2: Which dar'd to make a statesman feel?

line_1: "Work, feed thyself, to thine own powers appeal,
line_2: " Nor whine out woes, thine own right-hand can heal;

line_1: So from your Sentence they appeal,
line_2: Nor will be judg'd by Party Zeal.

line_1: To justice she may make her bold appeal,
line_2: Then conscious of her meritorious zeal,

line_1: To this one standard make your just appeal,
line_2: Here lies the golden secret; learn to FEEL.

line_1: Poets to ages yet unborn appeal,
line_2: And latest times th' eternal nature feel.

line_1: I to the weekly bills appeal,
line_2: Let those express my fervent zeal,

line_1: But will not Britain hear the last appeal,
line_2: Sign her foes doom, or guard her fav'rites zeal;

line_1: To HER decision make my last appeal;
line_2: To HER I bow, whose sacred power I feel;

line_1: From heads to hearts lies Nature's plain appeal,
line_2: Tho' few can reason, all mankind can feel.

line_1: No .... from my frantic wishes still appeal,
line_2: Or the keen hate for him I bade thee feel,

line_1: But, to the 'squire here, I appeal —
line_2: He knows my real value well:

line_1: Enforce each human suff'rer's strong appeal,
line_2: And teach the selfish breast what others feel;

line_1: Will Truth and Reason make their just appeal;
line_2: With friendly voice I call, and honest zeal!

line_1: Will Truth and Reason make their just appeal;
line_2: The health and sickness of the common-weal;

line_1: Will Truth and Reason make their just appeal;
line_2: The maladies you cause, yourselves must heal.
